Wonderful professor. Don't buy the book if you plan on going to the lectures -- haven't opened once and aced her midterm. She makes a boring subject incredibly interesting and easy to learn. Wish other profs were as excited about their subject as her.

You can either REALLY read the book and do research, or not buy the book and attend class and pay 100% attention. She is really descriptive and the tests aren't hard if you go to class. She made it interesting. As interesting as this subject can be to someone who doesn't care.
History of Art - She's a very clear lecturer. Don't buy the textbook, you never use it.

Great professor. Truly knows the topics she teaches inside and out. Answers questions very thoroughly. Opinionated, but very open to student opinions as well. She gives out all possible essay questions before the tests, which require some critical thinking but are perfectly fair. Class was kind of reading-heavy, but you can get by skimming.
Lisa is great. Makes things very clear, even if her own interests come out stronger than the students. (I think that's more the student's fault for not talking enough...)
Professor Florman is extremely intelligent and knows her stuff backward and forward. Her class was really interesting and I learned a lot!
this professor is very excited about teaching and helping students understand difficult concepts.

Lisa Florman gave the most verbally economical and concise art history lectures. That said, the material is densely presented, so be prepared to keep up. If you're listening, the material is fascinating and compelling. If you drift off, you may as well leave for all the good it will do you. Great class, learned tons, actually retained it.
Very good teacher...very clear on what she wants from you. Attendance is crucial to make sure you know everything she talks about. Would recommend this class
Good class

the original description of the class got me really excited but when i got there i was dissappointed, not because the class was bad, just because it ended up being something completely different than what i thought. we talk about critics, specifically greenburgh, rather than works. florman really knows her stuff though, and teaches it very well.

Very good lectures. Make sure you go to class everyday. She'll give hints for the exams on a days when there aren't that many people at the lectures. Overall great class, but tests are somewhat hard. Know your stuff!
No Comments
One of the best professors I've had at OSU.  Intelligent, professional and thoroughly knowledgeable about her subject. Other profs should follow her standard.
Great
The absolute best professor I have ever had. Plus she looks like Jodie Foster

Don't expect to pass if you miss more than one class.  She is very clear in what she wants from students.  Doesnt limit the viewing of art to just the classroom, she wants students to actually experience it themselves.
She is a very nice woman who tries to make her Art History classes enjoyable to those who don't know anything about art!

Paulsen's lectures were interesting along with the different films that were discussed. But you have to make sure to keep up with the class weekly since the majority of your grade is from two exams which are essays along with discussion posts and quizzes as well.

All I have to say is your grade is based completely off your two exams and that's it all the other assignments not only do they take hours and hours to complete their worth practically nothing. The workload is more than my core classes some weeks.

The content was pretty easy as long as you kept up, but keeping up was the hard part. I really didn't have an issue with prof. Paulsen, but the workload was way over the top. If film studies is a topic that you enjoy than this class may suit you, but if not, I suggest taking a different course if you're looking for a GE.

Email communication was reasonable- about 24 hours or less. Not too many assignments, but the ones we had were pretty lengthy. They weren't too bad if you did the readings. My only issue with Professor Paulsen is that I was .75% away from a B & I wasn't able to redo an assignment to fix it. Other than that, she was pretty okay. The TA was horrible.
Not too hard, generally enjoyable if you keep up with the class weekly. I enjoyed the course and thought it was interesting.
her lectures are interesting but the structure of the class is stressful, only 2 quizzes, 2 exams (essays), and 30% of the grade is participation which is really long and hard discussion posts

Ive seen lots of bad reviews on this class, however I did not think it was that difficult. It was asynchronous, however I never really watched the lectures (only the ones that were needed for exam essays). Theres not much to be graded on, so do not miss a discussion or it will tank your grade. For discussions, looking up summarys worked for me.

This class was overall easy, the final papers were ridiculous though. Prepare to spend lots of time writing finals that are the majority of your grade. Grading is way more difficult than it needs to be on the finals. Papers end up being at least 10 pages because the essay questions have at least four parts. Overall, wouldn't recommend it.

um. if youre taking this as one of several options for a GE.. DONT. tons of easier options. try ArtEd1600. if required for your specific major good luck. grading criteria on exams is extremely ambiguous, unless you genuinely love film studies DO NOT take this.

She seems pretty nice, lectures are easy to understand. You have all the answers for quizzes ahead of time. You can get away without doing a good chunk of the reading/watching movies and still get a fine grade. Asynchronous so for the most part you can really go at your own pace which is nice. Interesting class.

Tons of reading and writing. Not clear in terms of paper expectations. I did well, but I still feel the class needs to be far clearer in grading criteria. Exam is extremely long and lots of work. The class is less difficult and more time consuming. Often a movie each week, 3 hours of lectures, reading 20 pages, and writing a discussion post.

Class was completely asynchronous this last semester. Dr. Paulsen is clearly very intelligent and knowledgeable about her field, but her lectures can be extraneously long. The first week we had over 5 hours of lecture to view. It felt ridiculous but eventually evened out. The papers were rough, but the TA graded nicely. Put in the time, get an A!
Professor Paulsen gave extremely good lectures and it is clear she puts a lot of effort into teaching her class.

There is no reason on earth why a GE should be this much work. Maybe this course has never had to be online before? I have no idea. DO NOT take this course unless you're a film whiz. Zero communication from prof, TA grad students only. Low point assignments that will have you working for hours. Exams pretty much  grade. Horribly set up for online
I took this class as a GE online. The amount of coursework is insane. Most of the weeks you can expect to sit at your computer for 4+ hours reading, watching lectures, and watching films.

Do not take this class for a GE and do not take it over the summer online. The amount of work is absurd. I did hours of work each day and was still always struggling to catch up. Movies are extremely boring and so are the lectures. Grading is extremely harsh. Very difficult A.

I think Prof Paulsen is one of the best professors I've had yet. She's an amazing lecturer, which is definitely good because you probably couldn't get an A in this class without listening. Difficult class, but I really enjoyed it, mostly because of Prof Paulsen.
Took thinking it would be an easy A and interesting. I was completely wrong. Take another GE don't take this one. Assigns extremely long papers with material that is hard to write about.

Kris Paulsen is extremely passionate about what she teaches. However, I thought this would be an easy class, and it wasn't. One test and two ten page papers are what make up your grade. I would suggest taking a different GE if you don't have a heavy interest in films. She makes it as interesting as she can, but I dreaded going to class. Hard A.

I've never taken  a class like this before. Our entire class was designing and executing an exhibition in Hopkins Hall gallery. She is incredibly well- connected, and her organization is unmatched. This class gave me real- life experience, which is more than I can say about any other class at Ohio State.
Not really into modern art, but she is so enthusiastic and fun that it grew on me- her energy is contagious

This class was one of the best classes I had this semester.  Professor Paulsen makes this class super interesting and is very insightful in terms of film studies. Attendance isn't mandatory, but you won't get the information otherwise.  This class and her teaching inspired me to pursue a film studies minor.  I'd take another one of her classes!

Kris is energetic, and passionate about the art she studies. Don't miss the readings, and always, ALWAYS do the response papers. That's the only reason I got a B. She is a fair, yet understanding grader. Tests all essay questions, but she doesn't dock unnecessary points. I hate modern art, but she made it fun to learn! Take her class if you can.

She is an awesome professor! I absolutely love her analysis of films. I researched on the films we watched and couldn't find an insight comparable to hers. You do have to go to class.. it's not mandatory but you'll get most of the answers in her lecture material. Do take notes, they'll help when writing the essays. This class made me love old films

Worst professor I've had at Ohio State. All the exams are essays, and you receive a grade with no comments as to why you missed points. Rude in emails, and makes you watch terrible films. Good luck getting an A in what should be an easy class, but isn't. Only class I won't get an A in this semester.

Very passionate and enthusiastic teacher with some pretty funny comments. Very thorough in her material but she talks very quickly so sometimes its hard to get everything down. If you don't like reading critical essays don't take the class because there are a lot of readings you have to do and essay responses. Great class though!

She was interested in the topic, but really didn't seem interested in talking to the students. Her TA's did all the grading. If you take good notes, then you can easily get an A in her class. Just make sure that you are writing down everything she says about the movies, these comments actually help a lot when writing the exams..exams are all essay.

Kris was very excited about what she was teaching and that rubbed off on me. You can get an A, but you have to do the work for it. Very fair. I suggest typing out the notes in class! overall, love her!

I found Dr. Paulsen to be a really cool and engaging professor.  She made a topic about which I had negative feelings (contemporary art) very interesting and enjoyable.  If you need help in her class, go to office hours; she's willing to stay for as long as can reasonably be expected to help you understand a topic.

This is a really easy class. The movies were pretty interesting and everything was graded very easily. The only bad thing is it sounds like the teacher is reading directly out of a book during lectures, which gets boring after a while.

Teacher pics a horrific selection of movies that cannot be related to at all.  Lost interest in class immediately and attending class other than movie days not important. She butchers all movies we watch.
She is very passionate about what she is teaching and clearly states what to expect to be on quizzes and midterms
Terrible. She was barely involved in class all she did was upload pre recorded lectures. & I literally had a B- than she took off points for being late to online recitation. Like be forreal.

Professor Latorre is genuinely passionate about her job! I had her online, but the class was still engaging. Participation in recitation matters and is encouraged. You have a couple papers to write, but they are super easy. There is a weekly quiz, but you should do fine as long as you watch the lecture fully and complete the readings that are given

The professor literally tells nothing except the historical development of all kinds of power from special identity, require a high level of writing skills and grade really hard on midterm and paper, it supposes to be a GE that not ruin GPA, but it did. it requires four papers in one semester and averages 80%, you can't get an A if you are normal.

Such a great professor who truly cares about what she's teaching. Also very understanding about situations. A few papers to write over the semester graded by GTA's and easy quizzes and exams if you watch the lectures/ do the readings. Readings can be long though.

Professor Latorre is one of the best professors I've had at OSU. She is so passionate about the topics covered in class and does her best to be empathetic and understanding in hard times, specifically amid COVID. Participation and attendance are mandatory, but I've found her class is very engaging and interesting.

Professor G is amazing. She truly cares about her students and is incredibly inspiring. She creates an extremely inclusive atmosphere and creates opportunity for wonderful conversations. I have learned so much about feminism from this class and I recommend it to anyone. Weekly quizzes on lectures and readings and essay based exams aren't hard.

AU 19. This class made me critically think, and I actually liked the recitation participation activities. Doesn't post the lectures, so you will need to attend them. Keeps track of attendance as well so show up (or your grade might hurt). You will do good on the exams (which are essay based!) if you actually understand and think about the material.

This class was very easy BUT she is very unorganized (changes up dates things are due, does not put changes on Carmen, etc.) You get two unexcused absences but any after that is 10% off your FINAL GRADE. Exams aren't too difficult but there is a lot of material to study with the format being 5 fill in the blank (no word bank) and 1 essay.

She assigned so much reading. We had a discussion every Friday, which was kind of boring. I liked her as a person, but not so much as a professor. She's very nice, but expects a lot out of her students.
I love her. She is one of the most caring professors I've had at OSU. She listens and empathize. This class inspired me in so many ways I truly appreciate it

She is easily one of the best professors I have taken class from at OSU. She is inspiring, gives a ton of extra credit opportunities, and is super real. We barely had homework due aside from the readings for recitation every week that were usually interesting, so not a struggle to get done. I recommend this class/ professor to all.
Super clear about what would be on midterm & what she expected on the papers. Gave extra credit. two midterms (second is the final but same format as midterm) and two quizzes. easy class.

Mrs. Latorre is an excellent Professor. She is very helpful, very interested in her work, and she is always welcoming students to participate. One thing, however, is that if you're like me, and had to take this class without any interest in learning about the arts, it was very hard to keep any interest throughout this class. Take it if you like art

Professor Latorre is incredible. She is extremely knowledgeable and approachable. She is really nice, super smart, and very interested in student comments during discussions. She makes you think about art and women's studies in ways that you probably haven't before. Take a class with her!

Shes an amazing lectuer, she goes into depth for artworks/events and connects them, makes it interesting.However,I hate the wordload is managed. She always crams papers, exams and expects you to read a 30page article and write about it over a few days. Exams are tedious like taking an AP History exam. I would avoid it just because of the workload.

Does not care about students' wellbeing or time. Refuses exam makeups, or even taking them early--even if student has circumstances in which they physically cannot be in class during the time of the test. Very heavily Christian-leaning course content and views. Not clear grading criteria. Vague exam questions. At least there's no group projects.

Amazing professor. You can tell she is passionate about what she teaches, and is caring and willing to answer any questions you may have about the subject or any assignments. The class has only a few graded assignments: two tests, a final paper, and four short response papers.Would definitely recommend if you have an interest.
Solid professor. Very clear criteria and very clear on what would be on exams. Not a ton of homework which was nice. Fair grader. Overall a very solid choice for Art History.

I honestly hated this class. All of the movies were in a different language which is fine, but I have a hard time understanding movies and don't really like movies. The class is easy though, just make sure you do good on your reflection essays with comparing two movies of your choice! But each week you watch a movie, do a discussion post

Class was heavy with readings and writing, but no tests for a 4 credit class. Watching movies is also a lot of time because you often have to rewatch it. Great professor and super willing to bounce ideas and collaborate with during lectures. Super friendly to students who have no background in film or HISTART.
I actually took 5910, Documentary Cinema, as well as online global cinema with her. She was wonderful in both classes. Interesting topics, not too much work, communicated in a clear manner.

This was a pretty easy class. I didn't watch the full movies and still got an A. It is nice that you can do the work when you want but be prepared to write pretty lengthy discussion posts each week. You also have to respond to someone each week to get full credit. There are two bigger papers but are based on your opinion using sources from class.

This was a completely online course, and it was very straightforward. You have to watch a movie every week and respond to discussion posts, but even though it takes time it's very easy. The only real assignments are discussion posts and two reflection papers, but this class is super manageable.

Professor Levin is a kind and caring professor. Lectures were always super fun & engaging. She made sure that none of her students got left behind and would send a "checking-in" email if you missed a few classes to make sure you're okay. Levin was probably one of my favorite professors. She was passionate about the lectures & assignments were easy.

Easy A and somewhat enjoyable work. Watch a movie every week and have to critically answer a few questions. Helpful to be in a class GroupMe if you have questions. Only 2 papers and Prof Levin is an easy grader/and responds fast to emails. If you can manage to watch movies with CC for 4 months take this class for an easy grade!

Movies are really depressing or non-mainstream. Never did any of the 30+ page readings but I would suggest you know how to use F9 and hopefully youre in a class groupme. Always watched the movie and did the discussion post the day of or day before. Tedious work, but manageable.
She was my worst professor. Every week had at least 50+ pages to read for a possible quiz! Do not take her! You will regret it! Quizzes are not clear and hard, impossible

Erica's great and she teaches a fun class. It was always engaging, interesting, full of good discussions, and also had a very manageable/reasonable workload. I'd definitely take another class with her. Plus, she's super kind and has a sense of humor! What more could you want?

Professor Levin is passionate about the topics discussed in class. Films are viewed weekly, outside of class, along with a weekly reading. The work load is very manageable. I recommend doing the study guides every week as well as taking a few lecture notes. I loved this class and learned so much. There is one paper, 5 quizzes, and one final.
Lots of lectures, but her passion for the subject material shines through. So much knowledge. She appreciates contribution but it's not required.
Yikes
Unless you have to take this course, don't. And if you hope to see an uplifting movie, you won't. Quite the opposite actually.

Some of the movies are pretty boring, but overall it is a great class. She tells you exactly what you need to know for the quizzes and exams and gives pretty interesting lectures. Quizzes are pretty easy, but make sure to read the passage in the textbook and watch the movie.

Professor Levin is such an awesome lecturer. He lectures may be long and boring, but they're full of a ton of information. The class itself is easy and she makes it even easier. You watch movies every week and take a few open note quizzes. The midterm was take home and the final ended up being a take home exam as well. I recommend this class
Very nice and sweet! You can tell she loves art history which makes the class better. Sometimes she may repeat herself too much or go off on a ramble. Overall very good teacher.
Rebecca was great. She has inspired me to take more history of Art classes. She gets a grade of A+

You have to read. A lot. There are THREE required texts and you'll want to read them because the lectures are long and she is all over the place. I had a hard time following the "flow" of this class' design. Its a little confusing!

I studied with Professor Huntington in 1970-1974.  Yeah, not too many my people "rate their professors."  He changed my life.  He was an inspiration then and he is an inspiration now.  I consider him to be my sensei.  And I'm not even an art historian.  He was wise.  He was challenging.  He pushed me to my limits.  I have utter respect for him.

He s extremely educated on this subject but I think he fails to communicate the information in a clear manner that students can grasp. He is a crazy, cute old man but I have a problem in that we learned more about the presuppositions of Buddhism rather than art. I enjoyed the class but it was more religious studies based than art history course.

I had Professor Huntington for the history of Asian art. He is humorous when he talks about materials during lecture. No textbook is required. Attendance is not taken for the lecture, but make sure to go to recitation so you get to know things that might be on the exam. Ask questions if you don't understand what he is talking about.

Prof. Huntington knows a lot about Buddhist art.  I learned more in his class than I learned in any other class.  His teaching style is very laid-back, and he is always willing to help students outside class.

If you go to class, pay attention, and take decent notes, his classes are easy. On exams, you just have to say something relevant to each image shown (you're given the date/period/artist/etc.) He seems more concerned with you actually learning something than formalities. Very flexible, reasonable, and helpful. I'll be taking more of his classes.

I found that going to class was pointless because her powerpoints don't include a ton of detail. I only read the book when it came to exam time. Go to recitation for the class attendance.  If you just study the info from the study guide when it is exam time, you'll do fine. I got an A and never read the book ahead of time or went to  lecture.

Make sure you put in the time and effort because there is only one midterm, one final and an assignment. That said, her exam are  easy ONLY if you study! She gives a study guide way in advance (which was nice) and although there was a lot to knowmemorize, she was EXTREMELY fair in the exams as she only covered things that was covered in class.

Very intelligent and very eloquent speaker. Gets the point across very well. Heavy book usage (mostly readings and art analysis). The bulk of the work is in recitation where you will actually be able to put lecture materials to work and get information as to what to study.

She is a great professor who clearly enjoys her job.  She is passionate about art history and makes even the worst topics somewhat interesting. Attending lecture isn't necessary, but helpful. She gives a detailed list of what slides are going to be on both exams, but you must study to get an A! This is definitely an easy, yet enjoyable class!!

She explains everything clearly, lists everything that will be on exams prior to the exam, puts up slides with pictures and all power points on carmen. Provides several opportunities for extra credit. If you don't like lecture, its not really necessary. Everything is in the book.  I would recommend her.

Mrs. Fullerton is the best.  She is extremely nice and will help you out in any way she can.  If you like art history, and you're not taking her class to fulfill a GEC req., you find her bery funny.  I would take any class with her.

mrs fullerton is a good teacher, she knows her stuff and clearly tells you what you need to know in class.  she doesn't give any extra assignments, just a quiz and exams.  you definitely have to study, but if you do, you'll be fine.
No Comments

Mrs. Fullerton's class was pretty easy. She tells you the exact format of the test which is very helpfl, and makes it fairly obvious what your gonna be tested on, she also didn't assign one paper the whole quarter. However, her class was very boring and you need to attend to get an "A."
This professor was very helpful and energetic.  She doesn't, however, tolerate students who blow off her class.  Although the lecture format was boring, she was able to keep my attention.
I learned so much. I wish I could have learned more. I started collecting art based on Odita's teachings and have done very well. Thank You.

Professor Odita means well but his class is a bit unorganized and his notes are in no way conducive to learning.  He simply reads what's on his powerpoints word for word (keep in mind these aren't available outside class).  He's a sweet man but I wouldn't recommend his as a professor.

His classes are nothing but strings of circular reasoning. He makes up nonsensical labels and relationships in art that no one understands, so it takes pure memorization to pass. He's incomprehensible unorganized. Just peek at the syllabus and you'll turn and run. Don't waste your time.

I loved this class and really felt like the information he gave although a little scattered and out of context reflects what Odita has to offer.  Pay attention in class and defintely take notes and you will do just fine. Hopefully I will see his show at the musuem of art in 2010.

Worst class of my life. The syllabus we received at the beginning of the quarter was entirely useless, messed up, and not up to date. He refused to believe us when we pointed out the flawed syllabus. His emails were so unorganized and the tests were terrible and over stuff we never learned. DON'T TAKE THIS CLASS EVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This guy should not have a job at Ohio State.  He is a terrible professor, often goes back on the things that he says.  Has no interest in helping students.  He stopped checking his email half way through the quarter.  Never was at office hours.  Overall worst I've ever had in three years at OSU.

Probably the worst professor I've ever had. He means well but he is hard to understand it terms of what he wants and what will be on the test. Tests are ridiculous. But he knows that people hate the class so there is a curve at the end

Means well but he insists on emailing us all of our assignments and addl reading materials; often the emails are disorganized, don't have the right info, are in some format no one can open. Syllabus very confusing to understand and asking him often gets you 2 or 3 answers. Don't take unless you love the topic or it's req -- it's a hassle!
great teacher
Excellent professor, helps you reframe thinking about African Art, past and present
a little unclear. but knowledgeable. knew alot of the artists we discussed-gave 1st person version of events--very cool. very nice person.

Odita is a good guy but his class is very hard, there's tons of work and he isn't very helpful.  The papers are long, most are easy to write, but the exams are very hard.  The class was a pain in the ass but he won't fail anyone and he does mean well.
fun!
great!!
really cares about students, fun Class
Good. Don't buy the book, you won't need it.

She is very passionate about her subject, but it makes the class more confusing. She is EXTREMELY scattered-brained and very hard to follow bc of very long, random tangents. If you don't "actively" participate and DO go to every class, you will only get and 85% in participation. DO NOT MISS CLASS. Exams are ENTIRELY writing (bluebook.)

Emma was a really good professor. She made content that could easily be dry very interesting because she showed clear passion for the material. She was very in depth with her teaching, which allowed for students to really learn from her. I definitely recommend Emma as a professor.

Attendance is required, but you almost exclusively watch movies, with some analytical discussions. If you're interested at all in film, this class is a great choice. Be aware that this is a class studying on the entire history of film, so until the last two weeks of class, the movies viewed are very old, but he tries to keep it interesting.
overall good guy. learned a lot.

Ron Green is possibly my favorite professor at OSU. It is easy to get a good grade in his class if you participate during discussions. I am not very good at essay format exams, but I was able to get an A. He is very knowledgeable and involved in film studies. Quit whining about the exams, participate in class, and try to learn something new!

The class was fine to fill the VPA GEC. Some films were boring. The tests should have been take home. He gives the question ahead of time and then you have to scramble to write 3 essays in 1 hr. The TA's also grade quite hard. Cracking an A is apparently quite difficult as they gave me 89 for all 3 exams even though I put in more and more effort.

He is very helpful and responsive! He DEFINITLEY knows what he is taking about in regards to film studies and analysis. Ron's a good guy - those who work hard will like his classes. Those who don't will probably dislike them. It is as simple as that.

Green's a good teacher for sure and he knows his stuff. The TA's grade tough but what can you expect when you are literally given the EXACT 3 questions in advance of the exams. Class Average usually a "B" with decent attendance rate. Take this or Art Educ for GEC VPA but you will learn more in this. And Green's good, just the TA's sometimes arent.

The class was very interesting and Prof Green definitely knows what he's talking about. The TA's all grade differently and some seem to have a bit too big egos. I feel that if Green graded my tests, my grade would have been better than it actually was. I hope they come up with a different exam method... it doesn't reflect a student's knowledge well

Absolutely ridiculous. Going into the class I considered myself a pretty big film buff. I have taken a film class the quarter before and received an A+. I walk out of this guys class with a B+. He wasn't clear what he wanted on the exams, there was unfair grading amongst the T.A.'s, I learned NOTHING useful in this class. BE WARNED!

he's really good for people who try i would take him again for another film studies class... he really knows his stuff and hes understanding/responds to emails quickly...worth taking for sure if you are a decent student!!! but art educ 160 also fulfills vpa gec and is a lot easier!!

Intro. to World Cinema isn't bad. It is sort of interesting, and it's taught pretty well I would say -- the TA's grade the tests which are all essay (questions practically provided in advance)...If you actually prepare (like write out in advance) you should be fine for a B or higher -- class average was usually a B or B-. Great for movie lovers...

This class was odd. Although you know what the questions on the test are prior to taking it, you really have NO idea what the TA's are looking for within your response. It appears that they have a set number of things that you have to touch on to gain certain points- but who knows what those are
Absolutely terrible. Disorganized and completely subjective without actually telling you what he wants until after you've failed.

He really loves what he does, that is clear.  The material on the other hand is so DRY and he loves watching silent movies, with no volume what so ever, and then lecture over that.  He goes over a ton of the same material, but seems to just repeat old information.

I disagree with the comment below this, his favorite word is "phallic."  He finds phallics in everything and loves to talk about them.  I do not respect Ron Green as a professor, he is the least stilumating and most unintelligent teacher I have ever had.  I do not believe him to have an academic mind, or at least he does not speak as if he does.

OMG i just stopped going to class because it was so boring but luckily he offered every movie in a computer lab whenever you wanted to watch it so i would just watch the movie the day before the test and i got an A-... so you decide..

i thought this class was interesting and dr. green made it that way with his knowledge and excitement about world cinema. plus, he gives you the essay topics ahead of time. so go to class, watch the movies, take notes, listen to what he says, and you're golden on the exams.

World cinema was cool, if you're not a morning person you'll definitely fall asleep. If you go most of the time, take notes, and listen to him you will do fine. He gives the essay questions and so long as you mention what he says in class, you will do well.

This class was something awful.A straight-A student and loving movies coming in, i had high expecations. Little did i expect a C. He gave us the ?s before the exams (three essays each exam) so you'd think its easy.So i used notes and the book to write down answers, then memorize them, and put them on the tests. yet i got a C. he never explained why

Not a bad class. Some of the movies where very disturbing, and the entire grade is from in-class essays, but I did alright. And now, if anyone starts talking about the history of documentary cinema at a cocktail party, I can jump right in and not embarrass myself or The Ohio State University.

Prof Green's classes are interesting and not very challenging.  He knows what he's talking about, although he does have a tendency to relate most things back to his own political views.  I've liked almost all of the foreign films he's shown, as well as the contemporary ones.  Go to class and take notes, there is no way you can fail.

Prof. Green often brings up his personal political views despite their irrelevance.  I was often frustrated by his blatent, yet expected, liberalism.  He had the nerve to say he wasn't trying to impose his views on anyone, but that is impossible to believe.  The class itself is pretty easy if you go and pay attention.

The class is pretty boring and we only got to watch a few films. Though he gives you the exam questions, he doesn't ever really lecture or teach you anything. Not a hard class, but I wouldn't recommend it.

In a world cinema class, you should play world cinema!!! John Wayne does not count!!! Very few world movies. He even let us pick two and of course no one picked any world movies!!! He also changed some questions on the test (he gives them to you in advance) and then you end up getting a bad grade!!!

I really feel like I learned a lot deal from this class. I was exposed to a variety of films I otherwise wouldn't have. Take notes on the films and he tells you the essay questions before the test. It took some work, but it paid off with an A and I'm not artsy at all

One of my easiest classes.  Cool films (if you like films from the earliest ones up until Garden State), and since it's in the Wexnerthere are comfortable seats.2 midterms and a final exam.  All you have to do is write what he wants to hear and you will get an A -guaranteed.  I got a 100%, 97%, and another 100%- and I didnt go to class a lot.

The guy is very smart. Class can be boring at times, and having the lights dim doesn't help you stay awake either. But he shows a great variety of films, tells you exactly what he expects on the exams, and reiterates the important parts very clearly. I reccomend him.

I really thought that taking a World Cinema class would be interesting (plus the course simultaneously fulfilled 2 GEC requirements.) However, I have to agree with the guy that suggested buying some Criterion Collection DVDs instead. The two weeks that Green set aside for both a Men's Choice and Women's Choice film were just a waste of my time.

I took four of Prof. Green's classes and truly enjoyed them all.  His teaching style was very comfortable and made you develop your own ideas.  He's also very helpful and knowledgable on films and film history.

Prof. Green is placated and nice when he's hearing his own voice, but as soon as you try to interject he turns into an arrogant **** whose word is God.  If you like debating one-on-one, fear this man.
If you enjoy film you will love him; because he loves his job and he loves film. How can you go wrong?

His appearance and his general nature screams pretention, but as far as his lectures and teaching style go, I think he's a good professor. If you pay attention to what he's saying and show up to class every day, you'll barely have to pick up the book. Plus, he let's you know what the exam questions are almost verbatim. Not a bad guy.
One of my best profs at OSU. Attend every lecture and take notes. Don't need to read the book until you know the essay questions. This will get you an A.
No Comments
Worst teacher I have ever had in my life.  never showed up to class and wasn't concerned about his students at all.  He should be forced into retirement.

He knows everything there is to know about film, and if you can manage to stay awake during the films you'll learn alot too.  Only workload for the class is 3 exams which consist of 3 essays each, and he gives you the essay questions in advance.  Not really hard, but not really simple either.

I didn't think that this class was all that good. The movies were uninteresting, his commentary was obnoxious, and the book is a waste of time. On the upside, you know what the questions to the exams will be ahead of time so it's not a hard class. Just not that interesting if your not into film.
I watched a lot of movies I wouldn't have normally watched and I enjoyed myself. PLus, he gives you a good idea of what the test questions will be ahead of time.

Very concerned with portraying world cinema. He even manged to slide in some films from Russia and elsewhere while teaching the Hollywood form to contrast.  It seemed tedious when he stops the film at first, but turns out very informative session about filmmaking and theory. Great professor.

Deceptively titled "Intro to World Cinema," Green filled the time principally with Hollywood productions. No big deal, if you can tolerate the pompous, uninformative commentary in sweater vest and tweed jacket and overall butchering of the films. Buy a couple of Criterion Collection DVDs instead.

Prof. Green is nice and approachable.  He is very knowledgable in his field, which is a plus because his passion in films helps make the lectures more interesting.  He's always willing to help, and he frequently asks the class for feedback on lectures/notes/readings to benefit us.  I learned A LOT.
He knows film, that is for sure.  I learned a lot in his course.
Essay exams were a bit difficult and grade was not curved. Class was good though, actually enjoyed it. Good guy, pretty helpful.
Tends to ramble a lot but generally an easy class and a good diversity requirement.  Can be repetitive but overall nice enough.
Not great, but not bad. Be very prepared for exams and write interesting extras and read the book to get an A! Good personality. Easy-going if you ask him to change something.
Great guy, made the Class interesting even if you were not an Art major the other teacher with him not so much.

Javier is an enthusiastic and engaging lecturer. He has expectations, but he constantly repeated the important information, and his jokes helped me remember the facts. Don't buy the textbook. You will have to take good notes though.

He is great at making you understand art. Very engaging and funny. The lectures are well organized. You do not have to buy the textbook, but you have to write down everything he says during lecture cos the exams are made up of long essays.
Humorous and very effective. you gotta love that accent too.
Fair grader, though you have to work for it. Never boring. Recommended.

He has a heavy accent but if you pay attention, you should not have too hard of a time understanding.  The class, is very, very hard. You need to constantly be studying and prepare for the midterm and final before hand and meet with him to go over outlines and essays. If you don't, you're screwed.
Super thick accent very hard to understand. Do not take as GEC. This class is more work then my engineering classes
Expects you to think for yourself. Great experience.
the only interesting history of art teacher i've ever had
Super gorgeous and hes like my only reason for going to class...he repeats too much but i dont care he's sweet and nice to look at
He is so cute! And he is the eastest grader.
super hot!!! really good ta too. he knows a lot about history of art and gets really into it, but he's very cool and pretty lenient. participate and in class and he'll love you.
He's such a nice guy

I had him for recitation for Art History and he was one of the best teachers I have EVER had.  Very helpful and truly eager to help students do the very best they can!  He does a great job of laying everything out for you without actually doing the work for you.  I highly recommend him!!
This was a fantastic class.  He made the subject matter interesting and had a clear and organized method of teaching.  I would recommend this class to everyone.  Great teacher.
He's wonderful and full of passion about this class. Nice person and not easy grader. I liked him a lot.

He's super smart (and GORGEOUS!) and a great teacher. As an art history major who had to take this class in my senior year (long story), I have to say having something dreamy to look at made this class much better.

Really fun and enjoyable class. Prof. de Louche was really cool and made strong and focused points for us to follow. Nothing was ever unexpected and I felt prepared for both the tests and the paper. Take this class with him if you get a chance!
He is very well educated and loves to teach about his subject. He wants to see his students do well. He can explain things very clearly. TAKE HIS CLASSES. Great TA...one of the best I've ever had.
he is very interested in helping the students understand what the professors are expecting from the students.
A truly helpful TA, I would like to be in his class again if I'm taking another history of art class.
He was awesome! He made the material extremely accessible and actually made Art History kind of fun. He was only a TA when I had him, but if he ever becomes a Professor SIGN UP FOR HIS CLASS!
No Comments
Did a wonderful job in recitation. Had a good understanding of what was expected on exams and conveyed information well. He is a fair grader and is willing to help if you are willing to ask.

Groseclose is awesome! Our class project was to analyze a collection of original, mostly unpublished Lewis Hine WWI photography in OSU's Special Collections Library. Very cool! Some people may consider her tough, but she won't let you take her class and not learn something, and I think that's admirable.

Groseclose is awesome! Our class project was to analyze a collection of original, mostly unpublished Lewis Hine WWI photography in OSU's Special Collections Library. Very cool! Some people may consider her tough, but she won't let you take her class and not learn something, and I think that's admirable.

I really enjoyed going to her lectures, a lot of material was covered and she really tried to engage with the class. Beware - if your writing skills are not up to snuff you may want to take a remedial English class or make use of the writing lab. Getting a decent grade on a paper means proper grammar and good context.
she is though but at the end of the class i feel that my writing skills have grown tremendously. she's very nice if you ask for additional help.
She's tough and demanding and not very generous when grading, but you will be a much better writer when you're through with the class.
This professor wants to help you, but is so ridiculously confusing! Terrible communicator, terrible teacher. She should think about leaving academia.

Her passion for History of Art is very obvious, but she tends to go on and on, but don't they all? I love it as well, but she made me not enjoy it at all sometimes. She came off as a bit degrading to students when they answered her questions in lecture - don't mispronounce anything and call a painting by its name! My TA wasn't the most helpful.

Very very gentle and nice person. Very helpful lady who helped me even when I am only a freshman(she is a a widely published professor in her area of expertise). Was not interested in class initially but after doing the readings, I grew interested. Take a small class with her, she will blow your mind.

I took this as a GEC class..big mistake. She is beyond boring and she makes up tons of words. My TA was awesome and really helpful but Mudrack had next to no organization in her lectures. She needs more bullet points instead of essays in her lectures to clarify- you cover a tons of art.
great teacher! if you go to class and study images easy a! great interest in material and loves teaching! take this class as long as your willing to put in the work

This is the best class I've ever had! She has great passion of teaching and I did learn a lot from her lecture. Although it's not a easy A class, but be sure to attend her lecture and recitation. Textbook is kind of useless.

i was not interested in history of art but she actually makes it pretty interesting. she absolutely loves this stuff and gets so into it. i suggest you go to lecture because sometimes she sends around a paper to see who comes and lectures are really helpful

Aron is by far the best prof I've had at OSU.  He is on sabbatical writing a book until 2011, but when he is back, everyone interested in art, art history, architecture, and/or art theory NEEDS to take at least one of his classes! Attend class, read most of the articles, and participate LOTS and you'll earn his respect and an "A".

I hated this class with a passion. Too much reading to do. I eventually realized that I didn't need to read the articles to be ok for the midterms. As long as you are actively listening/taking notes in class you should be fine. But definitely read your article when its your turn to present. He will make you re-do your paper if he doesn't like it.
Awesome teacher, definitely one of the best that I've had at OSU. He was extremely helpful and easy to talk to, I would take another class with him.

He has a tendency to interrupt people during their presentations to correct them and say pretty much what the presenters just said, but how he wanted it said. He's also kind of a braggy person. I would say he's a hard grader on papers, but overall the class isn't too bad as long as you arn't taking 18 or 20 hours like I was.

I thought that his class was just going to be learning about art, but was instead about art history. I though he is a very hard grader of my paper and exams. You will receive difficult articles to read and one of which you will present to the class and write a paper based on it. Make sure to do you reading and GO TO CLASS!

Prof. Vinegar is great. There was no textbook, all readings were on Carmen. Big focus on class discussion, his goal was to get the class involved. 1 paper, 1 class discussion leadership, 1 midterm, and a take home final. Easy so long as you go to class and actually do the readings. You will learn a lot, and Prof. Vinegar is engaging and pleasant.

dr. vinegar is EXTREMELY knowledgeable. I learned so much from him, and in much greater depth than any other typical lower level art history class. the clincher for me was when we had a take home final because he was delivering a lecture in paris that week. total badass.

Awesome Guy. Extremely interesting class. One of my favorite classes i have taken at OSU. Not hard at all if you study for the three essay exams. Just make sure to put in as much detail as you can. Got a 100%. Vinegar=Good Dude.
Interesting lectures, I would choose him again for another class.

Sometimes he can be a little hard to follow. Overall it isn't very bad. Going to class is really important because what all the exam questions are going to cover. He grades pretty leniently, so if you take it and think you did poorly on the exam, you probably did a lot better than you think.

More concerned with his own moronic concepts than actually discussing contemporary architecture. Ribbons? Strips? Clouds? Oh and let's no forget that Ryan Adams quote... ugh... lets see some actual buildings.   The weight of this class is unbearable.
a very conceptual class, vinegar is very intelligent and weaves an interesting narrative in lecture about architectural themes that i as a history of art major was unfamiliar with.
This teacher is one of the best teachers I have ever had class with plus he is very interested in what he's teaching

Coolest prof I've had in my first 2 years, gives test material and what he expects ahead of time and grades pretty lenient.  Going to class is the key, but its fun and interesting.
Very cool... very intelligent...
Dude was like a parole officer.  My buddy had to check in with him prior to Art History class because he received a D on the first test.
One of the best lecturers I have ever had.(HISTA means HIST ART)

Dave was really great.  I'm not into art, but he always related things to culture and religion, and that got my attention. His lectures were clear, and was alot of help when I needed help understanding the material.

This dude lives in the freakin' Stone Age. He used slides in his lectures instead of PowerPoints. SLIDES! The quality was horrible, dark and grainy and the projector kept breaking. The class would have been far more bearable if he were a little more with it as far as technology goes. Aside from that, way too much emphasis on class participation.

one of the few professors that ive had that goes out of his way to learn everyones name, and we had a class of about 70. encourages people to participate, very knowledgeable about the subject. his tests are cake as long as you go to class.
Horrible Class, requires a lot of memorization and studying. do not take as an elective, you have to go to every class and know everything he talks about

Mr. M is an excellant teacher who was extremly helpful and very, very, knowledgable.  His exams are typical history of art exams and are not at all difficult if you know the material.  Anyone who dislikes this sweet and caring man clearly isn't very intelligent and is upset because of the poor grade they recieved

Mr. M was a great prof! He is eager to help, is very excited to teach, and may bump up your grade for participation  and improvement on exams. The material isnt hard to understand, it just requires A LOT of studying to do well.

I just really did not like this class. I thought the subject of it would be interesting, and I love history of art classes, but this little man ruined it for me. I couldn't stand attending classes. He has a passion for his work, and in the field i'm sure he is great. But I didn't like his teaching.

A really good teacher. It is obvious that he really loves architecture and tries to share that with the students.

This guy is a horrible teacher and very very boring. His exams are incredibly dumb and makes them way too hard.Also he stutters alot and he kinda resembles Mr. Burns, so its hard to take him seriously. He's a big **** too
Very nice and willing to help students. Learned a lot. Materials might be intimidating but I didn't struggle that much to get an A. FYI, she speaks fluent English, so don't worry about that.
Nice, fun, and a definite hottie.
2nd class w/her. very sweet person. smart. funny. flexible w/schedule problems. great experience overall.
Good instructor!! she really makes us think ourselves about history of art.
Excellent instructor... her enjoyment for the subject was infectious!
